text: Your hear that? It's close.
Let's go give it a warm welcome.
I recently re-played The Witcher 3,
a role-playing game where you adventure through a medieval fantasy world as Geralt of Rivia;
a swordsman for hire specifically trained to hunt down and slay monsters.
What happened here?

Early in the game, there’s a side-quest
from a blacksmith whose forge was burned down

and who wants someone to find the arsonist in
exchange for gold.

After some investigating I found the man responsible,
and delivered him to the blacksmith.
Here you go, one village pyromaniac in the flesh.

But as it turned out; the forge was of high
value to a nearby stationed army,

and the soldiers immediately sentenced 
the arsonist to die.
No trial needed here, just a tree.

Even though he seemed like little more 
than a racist drunk,

I couldn’t help but feel a little guilty 
about the harsh punishment,
especially considering the fact that I had a chance earlier to let him go in exchange for a bribe,
and also because the army had already send for the supplies to fix the blacksmith’s damages anyways.

Harsh as punishment goes.
- But deserved.

The simple answer to why I felt the way I
felt is that I was empathetic to the situation

and the characters involved, and experienced
an affective moral response;

an emotional reaction to the normative judgement of an
action, in this case; the feeling of guilt

as a result of me not being sure whether or
not I did the right thing.

It’s an experience you won’t quickly find
in other forms of entertainment,
because unlike films and television shows for example, in videogames, players are active participants

with a considerable amount of agency, meaning
that you directly impact the virtual world

through actions and/or affect the story 
through narrative choices,

and these virtual actions can result 
in real moral responses.

The actions undertaken by players in a video
game do not occur in a “moral vacuum.”
– one study found -
Instead, virtual behaviors interact with an individual’s sense of “real-world” morality,

and thus, are capable of eliciting
[affective moral responses].

To most gamers, this experience of feeling
emotionally invested in the virtual worlds
of videogames is probably obvious and self-evident,
but when it comes to our actual understanding of it,
the exact nature of virtual empathy and the real world implications of in-game morality are still hotly debated,
and understandably so, because moral responses carry an important function, as another study explains;
Like any affective state, [a moral response] holds informative value for the person experiencing it.

[For example,] guilt can be understood 
as a spontaneous feeling

that “informs” a person that 
he or she did something wrong.
It's all right, it's over.
Leave me be, get away!

Affective moral responses put us in a state
of reflection, and, when necessary,

can subsequently guide us in altering our behavior 
and our worldview in general.

It makes me wonder what potential videogames
have by evoking such real world responses
in their virtual worlds.
Aristotle wrote that moral behavior is not a given, but something that must be practiced continuously,
something that one must get better at.

Can videogames serve as a virtual training
ground for real world morality?

Or to put it more simply; can playing a videogame
make you a better person?

And if so; what kind of game design is needed
to achieve that end?

There are many games that would serve as an
interesting case study for these questions,

but the one that stands out for me the most
is The Witcher 3.

Aside from offering an immersive virtual world
and compelling storyline,

The Witcher also made some really clever choices 
in its game design

that I believe encourage moral reflection in ways 
that few other games do.

So today, let’s take a look at the game design 
of The Witcher 3,
discuss the ways in which it makes players empathetic to its virtual world and characters,
examine how it gives them agency in order to successfully evoke affective moral responses,
and explore how this virtual experience can have meaningful real world consequences for the player.

Let’s start at the beginning; immersing
yourself into a virtual world.
One of the most investigated personality traits to discuss an individual’s relation to others is empathy;

the capacity to feel what another
person is feeling.
A study from the Amsterdam University took this trait into account when researching virtual violence
and found that their hypothesis;
“the stronger players’ trait empathy, the guiltier they feel when engaged in virtual violence,”
was supported by the results of their study.

What this suggests is that the immersion in
a videogame depends to a significant degree
on the player’s own capacity for empathy, and is not solely determined by the quality of a game's design.
That being said, there are several things game designers can do to draw players into their virtual worlds

and make them empathetic
to its characters.
The first is the external presentation;
things like character and spatial design, facial animations, graphics, sound effects and voice acting

all help to convey increasingly realistic characters 
and environments.
The second is world-building; filling the virtual space with a sense of history, culture and identity
that gives players the impression that they’ve entered a world that is relatable and believable,
that is made up of different peoples, classes and races,
that is shaped by complicated conflicts and power relations that motivate players to become involved,

make them want to invest in the world 
as if it were real.
Lastly, there is characterization;
the humanization of individual characters by giving them three-dimensional personalities
and rich stories and backgrounds.

This creates the impression that virtual characters
have their own individual lives
and do not solely exist for the purpose of the player’s advancement in the game.
This is obviously relevant for the main heroes,
but The Witcher shows how a little bit of characterization

can also do wonders at making players empathize 
with less noble characters,
and even make them feel for the monsters.
Anything I devour turns to ash, ash!
I cannot eat. The hunger is terrible, terrible!
See what I can do.

Assuming the player’s empathy and immersion
in the videogame world,
we can move on to the question of virtual morality and affective moral responses.

At the heart of morality lies agency; 
a person’s freedom to act,

and thus; a person’s freedom to act in a way 
that can be judged as right or wrong.

Of course, videogames by default already offer
some agency to players as all forms of gameplay
imply a certain amount of freedom of action,
like the freedom to move around or to overcome obstacles in creative ways.

But the kind of agency I want to focus on
is the freedom to influence the narrative,

to have the player’s choices matter to the
outcome of a story,
to have them be morally significant.
We can refer to this as ‘moral agency’.
While videogames have been exploring the implementation of moral agency since the very beginning,

it’s still an incredibly difficult feat
to pull off successfully,
because to ask for a realistic reflection of this kind of agency in a videogame really means to ask

for a game design that can predict and incorporate the
pretty much infinite entirety of human creativity.
This is why, at least to me,
moral agency in videogames always tends to feel a lot more limited than other forms of gameplay

that correspond more closely 
to their real world counterparts.

Some common issues I’ve encountered is that
morality is simplified to a binary design
of good versus bad where the player can pick paths between acting noble or acting selfish or even evil.

The limitations of this kind of design become
especially apparent when there is no real motivation

to alternate between options based
on specific situations.
In the Mass Effect series for example,
morality is presented as a spectrum between the heroic paragon and the ruthless renegade,
but because players are rewarded with bonuses the further they move towards one end of the spectrum,

they are encouraged to pick one end 
and then

make every decision in that direction without
actively reflecting on them individually.

So not only is morality limited to a binary
design, the multitude of these binary choices

that the game presents you with really are
just one moral decision
that you probably already made at the beginning.

Even when videogames want to present a more
complicated moral world,

you’ll often find that the actual design is still a binary one
where instead of picking between good versus bad

there is morally grey option 1 versus
morally grey option 2,
take for example the ending to Far Cry 4
where you can decide who becomes the new leader of the game’s world,

but each of the 2 candidates turn out to be
morally questionable.

The upcoming sequel to Dying Light also seems
to have such a system where you can chose

based on a moral belief, in this case; the
desire for stability, or the belief in freedom,
but you have to pay a price for it;
choosing stability results in an oppressive regime,
choosing freedom results in a violent anarchy.
While this kind of design might appear morally complex,
the player’s actual agency is still too limited to allow for real moral reflection.
As a matter of fact,
when the moral decisions you do make automatically lead to a rather extreme corruption of them,
the end result is more likely to feel cynical and may even encourage against moral reflection
as players become disheartened by having every choice backfire in some way or another.

Another common issue that relates more to
the story design

is that the narrative forks in the road 
can be way too obvious.

A game like Grand Theft Auto 5 for example
has a mostly linear story with little moral agency
except towards the ending when the game basically pauses to let you select your desired outcome.

A lot of games have these pivotal moments
where it is clear to players
that they’re about to make an important decision.

The problem is that because the importance
of these moments is so obvious,

the choice becomes too analytical and probably won’t
evoke a strong affective moral response as these
“are generally the result of quick, automatic evaluations, or intuitions, rather than deliberate reasoning.”

A different, but somewhat related issue is
that when players make moral decisions,

the designed paths do not always conform 
to their intentions.

I actually came across a good example of this
in The Witcher when I met the sorceress Keira Metz

While she is presented as a friendly character,
one that you can even have a romance with,
there is one side quest where she wants to take some potentially dangerous notes from another wizard.
My initial instinct was to prevent her from doing so
but when I thought I selected said option the game apparently assumed I wanted to eliminate her,
Shut up and draw your sword!

and I was thrown into a combat situation where 
I no longer had any choice
except to kill her or be killed myself.

Being unsatisfied with this resolution, I
ended up reloading the game and finding out

there was indeed an option to take the dangerous
notes while still maintaining Keira as a friend,
It seems I find it hard to refuse you, handsome.
it just wasn’t as clear as it could have been.

It should be noted that none of these issues
are game-breaking problems
and didn’t diminish my overall enjoyment of them,
but they are moments that make you aware of the limitations of the game’s design
and in doing so, can result in a temporary detachment from the virtual world

that prevents you from experiencing
real affective moral responses.

Now that we’ve discussed the challenges
and limitations of designing moral agency,

we can examine how The Witcher utilizes creative
solutions to give players
a more authentic feeling of moral agency,
and how I think these can successfully evoke genuine affective moral responses.

For starters, there is no obvious honor system
or morality meter.

Instead, Geralt’s nobility is mostly left
up to the subjective judgment of the player.

As such, moral decisions are not so much motivated
by the anticipation of in-game rewards or

punishments, but are rather a reflection of
the player’s own beliefs and character.
You'd like a reward I suppose?

You don't owe us anything. 
You were in need, we helped.
And they call witchers heartless..

This freedom to rely on your own judgement
is complemented by the intricate quest design.

While most quests are not that complicated 
in themselves,
there is a lot of variation in the way they are designed,
and even the secondary quests and Witcher contracts often have some small twist to them

that engages the player’s moral agency 
in a unique way.

During your adventures, you’ll be faced
with moral dilemmas;
tough decisions between equally undesirable options.

There are tests of conscience; moments where
your resolve might be put the test,

where you’ll be enticed to take bribes, 
to lie for your own gain.

There are moments where a lie might be the
considerable thing to do,

to protect others from harm, 
or from harsh truths.

Like already mentioned at the beginning 
of the video,
there can be times where your good intentions have unexpected negative outcomes.

But there are also times where your victory
is a real victory, a win with no strings attached.

There are also choices that don’t necessarily
impact the story in a significant way,
but that are designed to allow you to show character;
opportunities to be kind and generous,

You keep the coin for Mandy, her wedding, 
raise a toast to my health then.
Thank you, master Witcher.
Them's warm words, you have a good heart.
moments to show compassion.

The lord's son Florian and I, 
we loved each other.
Dieter walked in on us in the stables.
They drove me away.
Florian hanged himself.

The lord started drinking 
and the estate fell into ruin.
That's the long and short of it.
I'm sorry.
Ah, ancient history now.

Taken together, these different quest designs
offer a variety of morally significant situations

that keeps the players’ sense of agency
alert at all times.

It makes every opportunity for moral agency
feel fresh and in need of your full attention.

And because there is such a wide range of
possible circumstances and ways of engagement,

the potential for experiencing affective moral
responses is also much greater.

I don't drink with strangers.
- We share a round we won't be strangers anymore.

There will be times where you’ll be relieved
to resolve a conflict peacefully,
Thanks for not starting a row with those swines.

and times where you’ll feel justified 
in engaging in violence.

You hurt the woman I'm looking for, 
you tortured her friend.
And that's why I just can't let this go.

There will also be moments of mixed emotions,
moments where your beliefs are challenged.
You've killed 4 innocent people, at least.
And you? How many innocents have you cut down?

Moments where your feeling of accomplishment
at an earlier point is questioned at a later one.
I know him! It was him murdered some Tamarian boys back in White Orchard.

Thereby retroactively making you question
whether or not your actions
were really as justified as you thought they were.

These moments can be especially powerful when
it’s clear to the player that there’s no going back,

no checkpoint from 20 hours
ago to return to for a do-over.

In moments like these, the game deliberately
eliminates the chance to reload

and exercise your moral agency 
with an analytical mindset.

Instead, it forces players to reflect on and
learn from their affective moral responses.
This becomes especially relevant with the ending,

which is where I believe the cleverness of 
the game’s design shines the most.

For those who are not familiar 
with the game’s story,

the main plot revolves around Geralt 
trying to find Ciri,

a young woman who he had trained as a child 
and who is like a daughter to him.

Ciri is hunted by an evil force known as the
Wild Hunt because she is a Child of the Elder Blood,

the last descendant of a bloodline
that carries powerful magic.
I nearly killed you, killed everyone.
We'd all be dead if not for you.

Later it is revealed that, 
and we’re moving into spoiler territory now,

that the magical power of Ciri’s Elder Blood is also the
only thing capable of stopping the White Frost,
which is a more existential threat that is prophesized to freeze the entire world until it becomes uninhabitable.

And so after the Wild Hunt is defeated, Ciri
has a chance to prevent this apocalypse,
although it might require her to sacrifice her life.
And this is where the game reaches its climax.

You don't have to make this sacrifice.
- You're wrong. The White Frost is inevitable.
It will come to freeze the worlds, one after the other, eradicating all life.
As I’m sure many other players did as well, it is here that I was expecting the great moment of choice.

Do I want the ending to go left, 
right or down the middle?

In my head I was already weighing my options,
rationally considering what would be the best outcome.

And while there is indeed a great moment of
choice at the end of The Witcher,
to my surprise, it wasn’t mine to make.
It was Ciri’s.

This is my story, not yours. 
You must let me finish telling it.
There  are three main endings to The Witcher;

two happy ones where Ciri stops the White Frost
and becomes either a Witcher together with Geralt,
or the new empress of the realm,
and a tragic one where Ciri also stops the White Frost, but loses her life in the process,
leaving Geralt heartbroken and alone.
So if it’s not up to you to choose the outcome, then how does The Witcher decide what ending you get?

As it turns out, the most important factor
that determines
whether you’ll get a happy or a tragic outcome

is the amount of confidence Ciri has 
when she faces the White Frost,

and this confidence, in turn, is determined by
a number of small moments of moral agency

long before the actual ending where you were
able to comfort Ciri,

show her support, and make clear to her that, 
no matter what, you stand by her side.

Traveled half the world to find you,
but I never intended to force anything on you.

In my opinion, this is the true brilliance
of The Witcher’s design.

The ending is not determined by 
a momentary consideration,
but is a direct reflection of you empathizing with and showing compassion towards a virtual character
over the course of her story.
It is not outcome-oriented rationalization,
but pure moments of character that decide
whether you’ll end the game with a powerful feeling of accomplishment and relief,
or an equally powerful feeling of regret.
Lastly, let’s briefly reflect on the initial question;
can experiences in the virtual worlds of videogames have meaningful real world consequences?
Can videogames make us better?
While a lot of the research on videogames tends to focus on

how engaging in virtual violence could aggravate 
real world aggression,

the recognition that videogames can evoke 
affective moral responses
have opened the door to a more complicated dynamic between virtual and real world behavior.
As mentioned in the beginning of the video,
powerful affective moral responses can guide us in changing our behavior and worldview,
and so when a well-designed game like The Witcher 3 is capable of evoking such affective moral responses,
time spent in this virtual world might lead to meaningful moral reflection, as one study found;

Based on the present findings, we may speculate
that those players who feel that they are

doing something wrong begin to regulate the
noxious experience.

They may thus enter a more critical 
and distanced reception mode,
which may also serve to diminish the aggressive effects of the displayed virtual violence.

Note that this study primarily focused on
the experience of guilt,
the affective moral response to having engaged in regrettable virtual behavior or unjustified virtual violence.

When it comes to the potential effect of more
positive affective moral responses,

there still is a lot more research to be done, 
as another study points out;

Questions remain as to whether moral upholding
in virtual environments
(for example, being kind and compassionate) are equally as capable of eliciting positive moral emotions,
such as moral pride and elevation.
Nevertheless, The Witcher 3 has shown how great game design can draw players into a virtual world,
how they can become emotionally invested in its characters and stories,
and how a clever use of agency can evoke powerful moral responses that encourage genuine reflection.

But more than anything, it makes me excited
about the future of videogames
and the potential they hold in engaging and inspiring players in ways that other forms of media can’t.
Perhaps one day it will then become obvious to everyone what most gamers today already know intuitively;

that we enter these virtual worlds not just 
for escapism and entertainment,

but because they can offer truly meaningful
experiences that might just change our lives,
and ourselves, for the better.

I hope you enjoyed my first real dive into
the world of videogames.

I’m always excited about exploring the interesting
new ways in which we express ourselves
and try to communicate meaningful messages.
